Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: New Low Cost and Large Scale Manufacturing of Semiconductor Nanocrystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project describes development of a manufacturing method for production of large-scale, consistently high-quality and low-cost semiconductor nanocrystals, such as quantum dots. The unique size- and shape-related properties of these materials make them useful for light emission applications (including biological labeling and displays) or for light harnessing applications (solar panels). Despite the great potential of nanocrystal-based technologies, a major barrier is the production of high-quality nanocrystals in commercially viable amounts at low cost. The proposed research activities directly address these limitations through an innovative patent-pending low-temperature wet chemical synthesis route. Compared to the conventional high-temperature synthesis route, the advantage of this method is that it can precisely control the size and shape of products - properties that are necessary for successful incorporation of these products into end-user applications. Additionally, this method circumvents scaling limitations of conventional high-temperature synthesis routes. This Phase I funding focuses on demonstrating scaled-up production of high-quality nanocrystals with consistent, predictable properties using this low-temperature synthesis method.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is that it solves several challenges currently hindering broader commercialization of semiconductor nanocrystals worldwide. If successful, nanocrystals will be produced in large quantities, inexpensively and uniformly, resulting in a disruptive advance for existing markets and emerging applications. With greater availability and affordability, nanocrystals can be more easily utilized for energy efficient lighting and displays, improve color quality in displays (laptops, tablets, cameras and mobile devices), increase efficiency of solar panels, and penetrate more widely into applications in medical research, diagnostics and treatment. Emerging applications include the use of semiconductor nanocrystals for biofuel cells, lasers, fiber optics, electronics, security and surveillance, aviation and geothermal tracers. Given the immense potential of these materials in diverse market segments, the results from this effort can catalyze broader commercialization of these materials by removing the barriers to manufacturing. This research will also give a greater insight into the basic behavior of nanocrystals and into their formation and growth, issues which are essential for the design and incorporation of these materials into specific applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Navillum Nanotechnologies, LLC is a manufacturing company that manufactures raw chemical semiconductors, which encompasses semiconductor nanocrystals like Quantum Dots (QDs). These semiconductor nanocrystals are a new class of extremely small semiconductors that are unique in that they emit and absorb light within a specific wavelength range depending on their particle size.

QDs are a paradigm changing technology in a wide range of markets including optoelectronics (i.e., lighting and displays), solar energy, medicine, and many other market segments. According to Cannacod Genuity, the global market for QDs is expected to grow at an estimated CAGR of 125% from 2013 to 2022 reaching more than $9.6B. QDs are just now beginning to be introduced to the market with the first commercial display products - televisions and tablet displays -launched to the market in 2013. Other rapidly developing markets include healthcare, optics, sustainable energy, security and surveillance. With so many potential applications of QDs to choose from, our first target segment is the displays market because it provides us with already developing consumer products and therefore the fastest growing market opportunity, rapidly developing applications and technologies, and the broadest application market for QDs.

Three major problems have plagued QD production and adoption of QDs into a wider range of products despite their great promise for improving product performance and reducing energy consumption. First, traditional manufacturing methods for QDs require high “cooking” temperatures of at least 200 – 360 degree Celsius, making scalable manufacturing difficult and expensive. QDs currently retails at more than $2,000/gram. This limits QD use mostly to research and development, several in academic institutions. Second, it is challenging to produce consistently high quality QDs at a large scale because of the variability inherent in batch processing (i.e. same emission wavelength and narrow particle size distribution per batch, high emission brightness). Furthermore, it is even more challenging to produce the smallest, blue-emitting QD type due to fast crystal growth that occurs in the high temperature methods. Third, several of the well-studied QD types contain heavy metals such as cadmium and lead. These are already being regulated especially in consumer electronics. European safety standards prohibit the long-term use of cadmium and many other markets are averse to the material. So despite the growing demand for QDs, its commercial adoption has been slow and limited.

Navillum’s Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project successfully demonstrated the feasibility for large-scale production of high-quality bright cadmium selenide (CdSe) QDs at lower cost using our proprietary low temperature wet chemical synthesis method. We also demonstrated that our process produces QDs with a small uniform size distribution at consistently less batch-to-batch variability.  Compared to current market standards, Navillum produces QDs with superior wavelength control across the spectral range including synthesis of the smaller blue-emitting QDs (Figure 1), improved quantum properties (Figure 2), and enhanced production yields. Navillum’s QDs are stable and able to stand up to the rigors of commercial applications. For commercialization standpoint, this means that Navillum has the potential to quickly scale our production process while providing lower cost higher quality QDs, increasing its commercial viability by overcoming the main challenges hindering broader commercialization of semiconductor nanocrystals worldwide.
